utterances: The financial and mortgage crisis of course led to a rise in homelessness.
It's a problem we tend to see in an urban context, people living in boxes or shelters or tent cities like the one that got bulldozed in New Jersey a week ago.
But homelessness in rural areas is far less visible.
Desiree Wieczorek is 16.
She's in 10th grade in northern New York.
For about five months last year, Desiree and her family were homeless living in the woods.
North Country Public Radio Sarah Harris has their story.
Desiree, her dad Kenny and I have just trekked into the woods outside Parishville, New York.
The rolling farm land has turned into wilderness.
It's remote, wild with tall dark trees and a raging river.
It's hard to imagine that for five months Desiree and her family lived out here.
This is where we would bathe.
There is a rock right there that is like a slide that we would sit on and slide down into the water.
And it would get deep.
And this is where we'd go swimming too.
And we would hop every single rock.
The past couple of years have been tumultuous for the Wieczoreks.
Desiree's mom left her dad Kenny and took up with a sex offender.
Kenny had health problems and had to stop working.
He got custody of the kids and married his current wife, Missy.
Last spring the family was living in a borrowed trailer downstate and had to move out.
But they did have family property in Parishville where they camped every summer.
So Kenny decided to bring the family north.
I was happy because I knew I was getting them away from a lot of negative things and I was putting them in a positive environment.
Because, I mean, out here, I can protect them from pretty much anything.
But in the city, things come at you everywhere, you know?
For five months, the whole family lived in the woods in a small camper and a series of tents.
There were ten of them, Desiree says.
Kenny and Missy, the grandparents, an aunt, four kids and baby Cameron, who is just a couple months old.
We had no running water, no electricity and we would have to walk, like, almost a mile just to get to the camp after school.
Their camp was highly organized with specific spots for doing dishes and brushing your teeth.
They used an outhouse, cooked over the fire and even watched the occasional movie, running a laptop off the car battery.
A funny thing happened in the woods.
The Wieczoreks are a boisterous, loving family and they got to know each other better.
Because there was nobody around to communicate with.
We were pretty much by ourselves.
So we only had each other to depend on.
Eventually it came time to enroll in the local school, Parishville-Hopkinton.
Guidance counselor Melissa Scudder remembers being called down to the office to meet the new family.
(LAUGHTER)
I think at first, I was like, all right, 15 minutes - I'm out.
I'm done.
This is ridiculous.
It's so hot.
I'm so constrained.
And then it kind of just grew on you.
I think the longest that I went in was probably two and half hours.
The nurses were only supposed to be in with the Ebola patients in the red zone for 90 minutes or so.
The time Jen ended up in for almost twice that was because the generator died.
She says she was in the middle of setting up an IV drip for a patient.
J.
TRAN: The lights went off, and I'm just touching the bed, touching his arm, trying to find the pieces that I need to close the IV line.
There were a half-dozen other workers on the ward with her, but they couldn't leave because it was too dark to exit the wards safely.
Taking off Ebola protective gear is considered one of the most dangerous moments for infection.
While they waited, their goggles were fogging up, so they could barely even see.
J.
TRAN: There was one girl - her goggles completely slipped off, and her goggles were right here.
She couldn't see anything.
She couldn't open her eyes.
And you literally just had to hold her and lead her to the right area.
So...
A.
TRAN: They actually brought an entirely new generator after that.
Yeah.
Both Jen and Alex worked long hours.
Jen says it was a hard place to be a nurse.
The equipment was limited.
She didn't have access to monitors or drugs that she'd have in a Western clinic.
The majority of the patients on the ward were dying.
J.
TRAN: In one sense, working with Ebola is just trying to get Ebola-positive, Ebola-confirmed patients out of the community so they don't re-infect people.
So in some sense, it's like, oh, well, they can't stay here.
They have to go to this confirmed tent, and that's where they're going to die.
It was just - it was really hard.
You couldn't really do anything.
But she was so busy, she says, it was hard to take in the full magnitude of the situation.
Jen and Alex's parents, on the other hand, had plenty of time to think, and they weren't thrilled about their kids being in the heart of the Ebola outbreak.
J.
TRAN: So when Alex left, my mom was a wreck.
(LAUGHTER)
J.
TRAN: And so we're Vietnamese, and the nurse from Texas who was at NIH - she's Vietnamese, as well.
She's talking about Nina Pham.
It was all over the news at the time that Pham had gotten infected with Ebola while treating a patient at Texas Presbyterian Hospital in Dallas.
J.
TRAN: And my mom's a worry rat, too, so...
A.
TRAN: I think she was a lot more worried about you than she was about me because I wasn't going to be doing direct patient care.
Jen stayed in Sierra Leone for five weeks.
Alex stayed for 14 weeks.
They both say they're considering going back.
Alex says if he doesn't, he's been thinking about that refugee crisis in Syria.
Jason Beaubien, NPR News.

We look back now on the story that made big news in 2014 - tens of thousands of children illegally crossed the U.S.-Mexico border to flee terrible violence in Central America - in Honduras, Guatemala and El Salvador.
They made a harrowing journey across Mexico to seek refuge in the United States.
We've called two of our reporters who followed that story closely this year NPR's Carrie Kahn in Mexico City and John Burnett in Texas.
Welcome to both of you.
Thank you.
Great to be here.
And first, give us a quick overview of the situation for child migrants from both of your perspectives.
To begin with, is there still, John, a flood of children trying to get into the U.S.?
No, there's not.
The humanitarian crisis that the - President Obama mentioned over the summer is over.
The crossings of Central Americans fleeing the violence has really downed sharply.
And in its place, there's this massive border security buildup from the state of Texas, both with the National Guard and with just Texas state troopers everywhere.
But not many people are coming across.
And, Carrie, is that because things are any better for these kids in Central America than they were this year?
Well, the short answer to that is no, they're not better.
It's only been a few months.
And these are endemic problems of gangs and drug trafficking and violence.
And they're definitely not going to be fixed in a year or two.
You both spent a lot of time this year on this story.
I'm wondering if there are some especially vivid impressions that remain with you of covering the unaccompanied kids coming up from Central America.
I think one thing that sticks in my mind still is seeing these children from Central America.
And they were mostly young boys that I met in Central Mexico riding the trains up to the U.S.
They just looked so tired, and they talked about how hard it is to be a kid in Central America.
And just one other image that sticks with me - I talked to about 20 kids in a shelter for returnees in Guatemala.
These boys had been held in an empty warehouse by smugglers for 15 days with just rice to eat.
And they were stuck there and kidnapped, literally, until the Mexican army rescued them.
And those images just still stick with me.

What I remember is talking to a lot of these kids when they came across - and the harrowing stories that Carrie certainly heard - but really the scenes that turned border patrol stations into orphanages and complaints from border patrol agents that they were acting as babysitters - well, that's all over now.
And these unaccompanied kids have moved on to live with loved ones and family members farther in the interior where they're not as worried about the border patrol.
There was one - some brothers that I met from San Salvador, I met in June in their lawyer's office and then later in their mom's Salvadoran restaurant.
I went back on Sunday to go talk to them.
And now they're both high school freshmen - Gerson, who's 15, and his big brother, Darwin, who's 18.
And so I asked him to compare for me life in San Salvador and what life was like here in Texas.
(Speaking Spanish).
Carter said he was confident that through selection and training, the Marines will be able to make sure their fighting ability is maintained.
So most of the day the streets were very empty.
People were afraid to go out too far from their neighborhoods.
The only real traffic out there was people lining up at gas stations just to collect more petrol.
People that we spoke to were actually quite afraid of going anywhere in cars in case they ran across these fake checkpoints run by Sunni and Shiite death squads.
They would just stop and check their I.D.s and kill them just on the basis of their I.D.
cards.
Despite the relative calm, there was violence.
We had mortars in East Baghdad that killed at least three people and armed groups attacked police in Northwest Baghdad, and at least two police were killed in that incident.
And the morgue also reported receiving 64 bodies today.
Is there a sense that with last week's bloodshed that sectarian conflict has reached a new level?
Definitely.
We spoke to some Iraqis in downtown Baghdad today and some said they were just bracing for the worst now.
We found one store owner who is actually stocking up on AK-47s, just in case.
The last time things were this tense was when the Shiite mosque in Samara was damaged in February and that set off this wave of sectarian killings that we're still seeing today.
Since then, the Sunni and the Shiite enclaves have been firmly established in the city and the sectarian violence that happens every day really feels like all bets are off.
People have no more faith in their government.
People don't rely on the police.
They rely on their neighborhood militias to protect them.
One of the wildest rumors we heard while under curfew was that police in Sadr City were handing out police and army uniforms to Mehdi Army, which is the Shiite militia loyal to Moqtada al-Sadr.
And you can just imagine how people would react to something like that, especially given all of the mass killings that are supposedly carried out by these men in police uniforms.
Jaime, you noted that the Sunnis and the Shiites have retreated to their enclaves, but what about in those areas where the Sunnis and Shiites lived side by side?
What's happening in those areas?
Those are really the most turbulent part of the capital.
These are the places where there it's just tit for tat killings.
They're the ones who are most exposed to the mortar attacks and they're leaving because they have no other choice now.
There's nowhere for them to go.
